definition:
A poset $P$ is *locally finite* if every interval $[x,y]$ in $P$ is
finite. For example, $\mathbb{Z}$ with the usual order is locally finite
but not finite, while $\mathbb{Q}$ is neither.

Every locally finite poset is also chain finite, but the converse does
not hold. To see this, define a partial order on $\mathbb{N}$ by the
rule that $k \le \ell$ if and only if $k=0$ or $\ell=1$. Thus $0$ is the
minimum element, $1$ is the maximum element, and the remaining elements
form an infinite antichain. Every bounded chain in this poset is finite
but the entire poset is an infinite interval, so the poset is chain
finite but not locally finite.
